The '''Principality of Sealand''' is an [[List of unrecognized countries|unrecognised]] entity, located on [[HM Fort Roughs]], a former World War II [[Maunsell Sea Forts|Maunsell Sea Fort]] in the [[North Sea]] 10 km (six miles) off the coast of [[Suffolk]], England (51Â°53'40"N, 1Â°28'57"E).
The '''Principality of Sealand''' is an [[List of unrecognized countries|unrecognised]] entity, located on [[HM Fort Roughs]], a former World War II [[Maunsell Sea Forts|Maunsell Sea Fort]] in the [[North Sea]] 10 km (six miles) off the coast of [[Suffolk]], England (51Â°53'40"N, 1Â°28'57"E).
â   â
Stop Griefing Please.
 
Since 1967, the facility has been occupied by the former British [[Major (United Kingdom)|Major]] [[Paddy Roy Bates]]; his associates and family claim that it is an independent [[sovereign state]]. External commentators generally classify Sealand as a [[micronation]] rather than an [[list of states with limited recognition|unrecognised state]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Micronations|author=John Ryan, George Dunford & Simon Sellars|publisher=[[Lonely Planet]]|year=2006|isbn=1-74104-730-7|pages=8â13}}</ref> While it has been described as the world's smallest nation,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,22726244-5002031,00.html|title=JOURNEYS â THE SPIRIT OF DISCOVERY: Simon Sellars braves wind and waves to visit the unlikely North Sea nation of Sealand|accessdate=10 November 2007 |work=The Australian }} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Sealand is not currently officially recognised as a sovereign state by [[list of sovereign states|any sovereign state]]. Although Roy Bates claims it is ''[[de facto]]'' recognised by Germany as they have sent a diplomat to the micronation, and by the United Kingdom after an English court ruled it did not have jurisdiction over Sealand, neither action constitutes ''[[de jure]]'' recognition as far as the respective countries are concerned.
Since 1967, the facility has been occupied by the former British [[Major (United Kingdom)|Major]] [[Paddy Roy Bates]]; his associates and family claim that it is an independent [[sovereign state]]. External commentators generally classify Sealand as a [[micronation]] rather than an [[list of states with limited recognition|unrecognised state]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Micronations|author=John Ryan, George Dunford & Simon Sellars|publisher=[[Lonely Planet]]|year=2006|isbn=1-74104-730-7|pages=8â13}}</ref> While it has been described as the world's smallest nation,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,22726244-5002031,00.html|title=JOURNEYS â THE SPIRIT OF DISCOVERY: Simon Sellars braves wind and waves to visit the unlikely North Sea nation of Sealand|accessdate=10 November 2007 |work=The Australian }} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Sealand is not currently officially recognised as a sovereign state by [[list of sovereign states|any sovereign state]]. Although Roy Bates claims it is ''[[de facto]]'' recognised by Germany as they have sent a diplomat to the micronation, and by the United Kingdom after an English court ruled it did not have jurisdiction over Sealand, neither action constitutes ''[[de jure]]'' recognition as far as the respective countries are concerned.
